OF MOLECULAR CATALYSIS ELSEVIER Journal of Molecular Catalysis 91 (1994) 129-137 An alloy phase of Pd3Pb and the activity of Pb/Pd/C catalysts in the liquid-phase oxidation of sodium lactate to pyruvate H. Hayashi*, S. Sugiyama, Y. Katayama, K. Kawashiro, N. Shigemoto Department of Chemical Science and Technology, University of Tokushima, Minamijosanjima, Tokushima 770, Japan (Received October 8, 1993; accepted January 25, 1994) Abstract Oxidation of lactic acid was carried out in aqueous phase at 90 C at a controlled pH of 8 in the presence of lead-modified palladium-on-carbon (Pb/Pd/C) catalysts. The only Pd component detected by powder XRD in Pb/Pd/C as prepared was metallic Pd, while an alloy phase of Pd3Pb was identified in catalysts calcined at 500 C for 3 h under nitrogen. A drastic decrease in activity by calcination was observed for Pb/Pd/C, presumably due to the formation of a rigid structure of an alloy phase of Pd3Pb. However, the catalyst activity was regenerated by the recycle use, while unchanged the XRD patterns signifying that Pd3Pb was still present as the bulk phase. Enriched Pb additive at the Pd surface and facile rearrangement of Pb species in metallic Pd have been demonstrated by the XPS depth profile of Pd 3d5/2 and Pb 4f7,Z core electrons, providing a context of interpreting the regeneration of the calcined catalyst in recycle use. Keywords: Lactate; Lead; Liquid phase; Palladium; Pyruvate; X-ray diffraction; X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy 1. Introduction The attempted oxidation of lactic acid on Pd/C in aqueous phase at a controlled pH of 8 resulted in failure with no absorption of oxygen, while a spectacular change in oxidation activity in favor of pyruvic acid was observed on Pb/Pd/C and related catalysts [ 1 ] . *Corresponding author; fax. Hayashi et at. /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 91 (1994)129-137 CH3-CH-COONa CH3-i COONa +1/202 -+H20 (1) OH 0 Similar catalyst modifications for palladium and platinum have been proposed in both oxidation and reduction. Thus primary hydroxy group was preferentially oxidized on Pt/ C, while the preference changed on Pb/Pt/C towards oxidation at the position a to the carboxyl group in the oxidation of D-gluconic acid [2]. Lindlar catalyst Pb/Pd/CaC03 hydrogenates acetylenes selectively to olefins [ 3,4] . The catalyst Te/Pd/C was established in a commercial scale [ 5 ] for oxidation of butadiene to tetrahydrofuran through 1,4diacetoxy-2-butene [6]. Pb/Pd/C and Bi/Pd/C were used for oxidation of 1-methoxy-2propanol to 1-methoxy-2-propanone [ 7 ] . Formation of an alloy or intermetallic compound Pd3Pb has been suggested for Lindlar catalysts, Pb/Pd/CaC03 [3] and Pb/Pd/Si02 [8]. However, much emphasis on the crystalline Pd3Pb as an active species appears to have led to further discussions. We reported in a previous communication [9] that a trace amount of Te promoted the activity of Pd/C in the oxidation of lactic acid, but the Te/Pd/C catalysts were inactive at higher Te doping above Te/Pd=0.3 (atom), where Pd3Te crystalline phase was detected by powder XRD. In the present work, a drastic decrease in activity of Pb/Pd/C catalyst calcined at 500 C under nitrogen is demonstrated by the comparative reaction studies with XRD indication for Pd3Pb. However, the catalyst regenerated by recycling, gave an unchanged XRD pattern signifying that the Pd3Pb was still present as the bulk phase. XPS depth profile showing the surface enrichment of the additive lead is also given. 2. Experimental 2.1. Materials The substrate lactic acid was purchased from Tokyo Kasei and used as supplied. Authentic ethyl pyruvate used for the calibration of GC analysis was obtained from Aldrich Chemical. Palladium-on-carbon (5% Pd/C) and lead acetate trihydrate as a precursor for Pb/Pd/C were obtained from Wako Pure Chemicals, Osaka. Palladium (II) oxide powder and metallic palladium (100 ~tm sheet) as XPS references were obtained from Wako, Osaka and Nilaco, Tokyo, respectively. 2.2. Catalysts Pb/Pd/C catalysts were prepared as described in the previous paper [ I ] . The protocol for a typical Pb/Pd/C catalyst is as follows: To a flask containing 12.707 g of 5% Pd/C (5.97 mmol Pd/ 12 g carbon) was added an aqueous solution of lead acetate (3.58 mmol Pb/50 ml), refluxed at 90 C for 2 h, left to stand overnight at room temperature, and then an aqueous solution of trisodium phosphate added (4.78 mmol/25 ml; double the stoichiometric requirement) to convert all the lead into the insoluble phosphate. The catalyst Pb/ Pd/C (atomic ratio Pb/Pd=0.6) thus obtained was filtered and washed with hot water. A H. Hayashi et al. /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 91 (/994)129-137 131 half of the mass was reduced overnight with 15 ml of formalin and 10 ml of 30% potassium hydroxide, and finally washed with 1000 ml of hot water until the filtrate was neutral. The other half was calcined at 500 C under nitrogen for 3 h. Details of the treatment of the fresh catalysts employed in the comparative reaction studies are given in the text. 2.3. Oxidation Oxidation of lactic acid was carried out in aqueous phase (50 mmol/ 100 ml) at 90 C at a controlled pH of 8 in the presence of Pb/Pd/C catalyst (6 g). In the present reaction mixture, a molar ratio of lactic acid, Pb and Pd was 50:1.8:2.96 for Pb/Pd/C catalyst with an atomic ratio of Pb / Pd = 0.6. 2.4. Analysis Lactic acid and the oxidation product, pyruvic acid, were analyzed as the ethyl ester [ 1 ] by a Hitachi 263 FID gas chromatograph with a column packing of 15% PEG 4000/Uniport B at 140 C. 2.5. X-ray diffraction studies Powder X-ray diffraction of Pd/C and Pb/Pd/C catalysts was measured by a MXP system of MAC Science Co., Tokyo, at 40 kV and 150 mA with Cu Ka radiation. Catalysts were used once for the oxidation of lactic acid prior to XRD measurement. 2.6. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy XPS of Pb/Pd/C for Pd 3d5,Z and Pb 4fa2 core electrons were measured by Perkin Elmer Phi 5500 (Ulvac-Phi, Inc., Chigasaki), irradiated with Mg Ka, and the observed binding energies were calibrated with 285.0 eV for C is electrons. XPS results for Pd 3d-region of Pd/C, PdO powder and metallic Pd sheet are also given for reference. Argon-sputtering rate is not clear for the present system, but 2 nm/min for Si02, A1203 and MgFz as a minimum rate is given for reference. 3. Results and discussion 3.1. Oxidation of sodium lactate to pyruvate on PblPdlC catalysts A typical Pb/Pd/C catalyst with an atomic ratio of Pb/Pd=0.6 was prepared by the protocol given in the previous paper [ I ] in a scale double the previous amount. Half the mass was reduced with formalin/30% KOH as usual, and another half was calcined at 500 C for 3 h under nitrogen. Reproducible catalyst activity The open symbols in Fig. 1(a) are the results obtained in the present work for a fresh catalyst and the closed symbols are those reported in the previous paper [ 1 ] . Two sets of data are superposed together, showing the excellent reproducibility of the catalyst activity for different lots of preparations. 3.3. Calcined catalyst and use in recycle A drastic decrease in activity was observed for calcined catalyst as shown in Fig. 1(b). However, the calcined catalyst appears to be regenerated gradually during the reaction, and was used again after having been filtered and washed with hot water (without formalin reduction). The recycled catalyst shows activity, as shown in Fig. 1(c), which completely reproduces the activity of the fresh catalyst given in Fig. 1(a). 3.4. The only crystalline component detected for Pd/C (a) was metallic Pd (open circles), beside which was detected another component, PbC03 (open triangles) for Pb/Pd/C (not calcined; b, and c,). Enriched Pb additive at the Pd surface Powder XRD characterizes the bulk crystalline phase, but does not always give direct information about the working catalyst surface. Formation of an alloy of Pd3Pb extended over the bulk phase as evidenced by XRD (Fig. 2-c2) for Pb/Pd/C calcined at 500 C under nitrogen, and the calcined catalyst was inactive for the oxidation of lactic acid (Fig. (b) ). However, the calcined catalyst showed activity (Fig. 1 (c)) exactly the same as that of the fresh catalyst (Fig. 1 (a)) when the calcined catalyst was used again after filtration and washing with hot water. It is noteworthy that the XRD pattern of the recycled active catalyst was also the same as that of the calcined inactive catalyst (Fig. 2-c2), signifying that Pd3Pb was preserved for the recycled catalyst as the bulk phase. The results suggest the restructuring of sites at the catalyst surface, leading to a surface concentration different from that of the bulk phase. Fig. 4 shows an XPS depth profile of Pb/Pd atomic ratio for calcined Pb/Pd/C catalyst (Pb/Pd=0.3), where the surface was enriched with Ph additive, immediately followed by an asymptotic value of Pb/Pd=0.3 at the bulk phase. 3.8. Additive Pb in PblPdlC compared with Te in TelPdlC It is of interest that the inactive Pd/C showed activity in the oxidation of lactic acid in favor of pyruvic acid as Pb/Pd/C, Te/Pd/C and related catalysts [ 1 ] . Electronegative additives such as Pb, Bi and Te might deplete the electron density around Pd, resulting in the delicate change in the redox behavior of Pd/C [ 1 ] . An additive Te promotes the Pd/C catalyst, but forms Pd3Te with great ease [ 9 ] at higher Te doping above Te / Pd = 0.3 ( atom ) , and the resultant Te/Pd/C catalysts were again inactive. Similarly, Pb additive promotes the Pd/C, while an excess doping of PbZ+ on Pd/C does not cause the deactivation of Pb/ Pd/C [ 1,9]. The Pd3Pb phase requires calcination at a high temperature of 500 C (Fig. 2b2 and c2) and/or a prolonged period of Pbz+ impregnation of 600 h at room temperature [ 12], to be detected by XRD. Thus the rigid structure of well crystallized alloys of Pd3Pb H. Hayashi et al. /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 91 (1994) 129-137 137 shown for the calcined Pb/Pd/C in this work and Pd3Te in the previous paper [9J were unfavorable for the present oxidation of lactic acid. It is worthwhile to mention again that the inactive calcined Pb/Pd/C was regenerated during the recycled oxidation of lactic acid, while Pd3Pb was still present as the bulk phase. The restructuring of sites at the catalyst surface irrespective of the bulk crystalline phase was indicated by the XPS of Pd 3d5,2 and Pb 4f- 2 core electrons, providing a situation for interpreting the regeneration of the calcined catalyst in recycle use and the reason why the Pb/Pd/C catalysts were active even at higher doping of Pb additive. 4. Conclusions Pyruvic acid was obtained by the oxidation of lactic acid in aqueous phase at a controlled pH of 8 in the presence of Pb/Pd/C and related catalysts. The only Pd component detected by XRD for Pb/Pd/C as prepared was metallic Pd, while an alloy phase of Pd3Pb was identified for catalysts calcined at 500 C under nitrogen. The calcined catalyst was inactive, but revealed activity in the recycle use, suggesting the restructuring of sites at the catalyst surface. Enriched Pb additive at Pd surface and facile rearrangement of Pb species in metallic Pd have been demonstrated by the XPS depth profile. References [ 1 ] T. Tsujino, S. Ohigashi, S. Sugiyama, K. ( + 81-886)557025. Oxidation of lactic acid was carried out in aqueous phase at 90°C at a controlled pH of 8 in the presence of lead-modified palladium-on-carbon (Pb/Pd/C) catalysts. The only Pd component detected by powder XRD in Pb/Pd/C as prepared was metallic Pd, while an alloy phase of Pd3Pb was identified in catalysts calcined at 500°C for 3 h under nitrogen. A drastic decrease in activity by calcination was observed for Pb/Pd/C, presumably due to the formation of a rigid structure of an alloy phase of Pd3Pb. However, the catalyst activity was regenerated by the recycle use, while unchanged the XRD patterns signifying that Pd3Pb was still present as the bulk phase. Enriched Pb additive at the Pd surface and facile rearrangement of Pb species in metallic Pd have been demonstrated by the XPS depth profile of Pd 3d 5 2 and Pb 4f 7 2 Core electrons, providing a context of interpreting the regeneration of the calcined catalyst in recycle use.
